result.title: Objective
result.description: Ecosystem-based management in the HCLME is advanced through a coordinated framework that provides for improved governance and the sustainable use of living marine resources and services

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Agreement on and understanding of the ecosystem-level issues of the HCLME as they relate to management of living marine resources (LMR) and biodiversity conservation.

baseline.comment: Concerns relative to management of HCLME LMR limited to main shared commercial fishery stocks and impacts of environmental volatility

target.comment: Countries agree on the scope and priority of ecosystem level issues & develop interventions to address them in the SAP including management of shared fisheries from an EBM perspective

actual.comment: The TDA is approved and the final draft SAP, based on agreements made with both Chile and Peru Technical Working Groups, has been sent to both countries for their final comments. These are due 5th August and the deadline for approval is mid September 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Increase in the % of fisheries management decisions that are based on integrated information on multi-specific criteria and multi-disciplinary parameters, including natural and ENSO-related variability

baseline.comment:
Both Chile and Peru use single stock criteria for fisheries management, responses to ENSO are not precautionary but reactive
Note: A management decision matrix will be defined in year 1of project for monitoring this indicator

target.comment:
The shared anchovy fishery is managed using multi-specific criteria & multi -disciplinary parameters
At least 50% of the decisions in management matrix include multi-specific criteria and multi-disciplinary parameters

actual.comment: After a series of workshops both countries are getting closer to EBFM regarding both the shared anchovy fishery and others. Towards the end of 2015 there will be another annual binational workshop regarding the shared anchovy fish stock. These meetings were frozen from 2008 to 2014 and restarted after the marine boarder dispute was settled at the Hague on 27.01.2014.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Increased area of priority coastal, coastal-marine and marine habitats in Peru & Chile that are under some form of legal protection that contributes to biodiversity conservation.

baseline.comment:
Country & Habitat Area ha.
Peru:
Coastal 216,409
Marine 118,591
Chile:
Seamounts MPA* 0
Seamounts VME** 0
*Marine Protected Area
**Vulnerable Marine Ecosystem (VME)

target.comment:
Country & Habitat Area (ha.)
Peru:
Coastal 395,867
Marine 130,491
Chile:
Seamounts MPA* 8,300
Seamounts VME** 507,000
*Estimated by 1.5 m round seamount apex
**Under increased protection through VME protocol and fishing regulations; area estimated as per MPA x # of seamounts

actual.comment: The target level has been exceeded with 12,000Km2 of MPA confirmed in Chile along with studies to confirm where new MPAs should be established in years to come. In addition Management Plans have been drawn up for these new areas. In Peru Coastal Marine Spatial Planning work is going ahead and this process will draw on a range of studies carried out by this project and its partners regarding new protected areas. Furthermore all 118 seamounts are now protected including 3 in the Project's pilot site area in Chile as the Seamounts now form part of a Marine Park. Target exceeded in Chile. However additional MPAs * in Peru, although planned with Project assistance have as yet not been endorsed. * There are in fact no MPAs in Peru as the terminology used is Natural Protected Areas (NPA) and all current areas are a mix of land based areas with an extension of coastal waters associated.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Increase in the number of certifiable fisheries

baseline.comment: The necessary conditions for certifying a fishery are not yet in place

target.comment: At least one fishery has the necessary elements for certification

actual.comment: The first artisanal fishery in the SE Pacific has been MSC certified in 2014 (Juan Fernandez Rock Lobster Fishery). Other fisheries including the Peruvian Anchovy, Mahi Mahi, and Scallops are being assessed. The project's target has been met.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: % increased awareness in identified target groups, of the benefits of applying EBM

baseline.comment: % awareness of a defined number of target groups to be determined in the first 6months of the project

target.comment: 30% increase from the baseline value for each target group

actual.comment: EBM and EBFM among similar topics are now well embedded in both public and private sector mind-sets. Furthermore the IUCN 12 basic EMB principles are now well understood together with their means of implementation. The target has been met.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Planning and policy instruments for ecosystem-based management (EBM) of the HCLME are agreed and in place at regional and national levels

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: A Strategic Action Plan (SAP) developed based on up- dated ecosystem information and with an EBM approach is approved by both countries at the highest levels

baseline.comment:
There is currently no common planning process or definition of priority actions
Limited understanding of EBM

target.comment: Complete SAP is endorsed at the highest levels by both countries

actual.comment: The SAP has been finalized based on stakeholder comments. The final draft is back with the technical working groups from both countries for final remarks due 5th August 2015. The intention is to incorporate these final comments and seek approval mid September 2015. Coastal Marine Spatial Planning has been promoted by the Project with NOAA assistance in both countries. A USD70,000 NOAA Grant has been endorsed to promote the CMSP process in Peru. A Ministerial Resolution has been achieved to promote the planning process See: http://www.minam.gob.pe/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/RM-N%C2%B0-189-2015-MINAM.pdf

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: National Action Plans (NAPs) developed within the SAP framework and approved in each country

baseline.comment:
There are no national plans to prioritize actions for HCLM management.
Existing plans are sector based

target.comment: NAPs approved at the highest level in each country

actual.comment:
Although the SAP has as yet not been approved new NAPs are being approved like the ICZM strategic planning resolution mentioned above:
http://www.minam.gob.pe/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/RM-N%C2%B0-189-2015-MINAM.pdf

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
% of the priority actions identified in plans that have secure financing:
(a) regional level in SAP
(b)national level in the NAP

baseline.comment:
(a) 0
(b) Peru =0
Chile =0

target.comment:
(a)40%
(b) Peru =60%
Chile =60

actual.comment: A financial study has been carried out by the Project so as to suggest alternative ways of funding the Guano Islands and Capes National Reserve in Peru. This study is also of use to Chile regarding public-private methods of MPA funding.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Existence of short, medium and long-term targets for marine & coastal habitat conservation

baseline.comment: National protected area system strategies do not have specific targets for coastal marine conservation

target.comment: NPAS identify priority to reduce habitat representativity gaps and have specific targets & implementation strategies

actual.comment: Conservation objectives have been established in Peru and work to be finalized before the end of 2015 in Chile (Management Plans for MUMPAs and Vulnerable Area identification work) similar objectives will have been announced at the Our Ocean International event 5th & 6th October 2015 in Valparaiso, Chile.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of sectors represented and level of officials that participate in the national inter-sectoral committees

baseline.comment: To be measured in yr 1 as NIC do not yet exist

target.comment: The numbers of sectors represented and levels when NIC are first formed, are maintained and strengthened throughout the project

actual.comment: Participants within the National Intersectoral Committees continue to increase with new private sector and local NGO permanent membership. In addition work within the Communications Strategy implementation networks have brought more Civil Society Organisation groups into the cooperation framework.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Institutional capacities strengthened for SAP implementation and for up-scaling pilot interventions to the system level

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. % of effective information exchanges in protocols defined within the framework of the Ecosystem Information System (EIS)

baseline.comment: Currently, each government manages independent Geographical Information Systems (GIS) with limited information exchange.

target.comment: 70% of protocols for information exchange are functioning at least at minimal levels

actual.comment: Many information exchange mechanisms are now in place via the Communications Strategy and communications experts within all counterpart entities (brought together by the Amig@s del Mar initiative) See project website. Target reached.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: % of staff profiles and procedures that are aligned with EBM in key institutions (i.e., CONAMA, MINAM, SUBPESCA, Vice-Minist. de PesquerÃ­a)

baseline.comment:
<10% of staff in IFOP, IMARPE have profiles aligned with needs for EBM
Staff profiles & procedures for EBM will be determined in yr 1 once standards have been set based on agreed EBM definition

target.comment:
20% of staff in IFOP, IMARPE have profiles aligned with needs for EBM
70% of the research projects for resource management follow ecosystemic criteria
Targets for other institutions to be determined in year 1

actual.comment: Targets reached. The level of awareness within both public and private entities has increased dramatically due to both project capacity building work and the initiatives of both government funding programmes.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Key institutions (MINAM CONAMA, SUBPESCA), have the capacities and internal processes to prioritize the creation of new MPAs and to manage them effectively.

baseline.comment: Baseline to be established with institutional capacity scorecard values applied to relevant institutions on each country

target.comment: 30% above baseline values

actual.comment: Management plans for new MPAs are being finalized: in the case of Chile this amounts to new MPAs (Multiple Use) in addition to the identification of vulnerable areas to be given protection status in the future. Similar work in Peru has centred on the Guano Islands and Capes National Reserve (RNSIIPG) with additional areas being prioritized for MUMPA status.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Procedures defined and adopted to promote good fisheries practices and improve market competitiveness within the framework of the HCLME

baseline.comment: There are no procedures for promoting good fisheries practices in relation to market competitiveness in either country

target.comment: At least two mechanisms are adopted that promote good practices and improve market competitiveness within the framework of the HCLME

actual.comment: The Chilean Juan Fernandez Rock Lobster fishery received MSC certification early 2015. Market competitiveness has also been promoted for macro algae added value production from a 23km extension of algal beds in southern Peru and habitat restoration work covering 50ha in Paracas Bay Peru. Management plans for the co-management of other important fisheries including scallops in northern Peru have been established.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Improved understanding of the benefits of ecosystem goods and services of artisanal fisher representatives that participate in fisheries fora (as a proxy indicator of potential compliance with regulatory frameworks)

baseline.comment: Baseline level of understanding of ecosystem benefits in will be measured in at project start

target.comment: Increase of 30% above baseline values

actual.comment: In 2015 an Economic Valuation of the Goods and Services provided by the HCLME was finalized with a USD19.5 billion value placed on their annual delivery. Value addition work in both countries and analyses carried out under the TDA-SAP process have shown that while fisheries landing volumes are decreasing year-on-year their value are increasing.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Implementation of priority MPA & fisheries management tools provides knowledge of options for enhanced protection of HCLME and SAP implementation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Advances in adopting EBM for the shared anchovy stock as measured by the increase in agreed on and coordinated program of activities

baseline.comment: Current agreement between IFOP and IMARPE only includes information exchange on stock evaluations and reproductive parameters for main pelagic commercial stocks

target.comment: Coordinated management agreement includes the use of multi-specific criteria and multi-disciplinary parameters for the establishment of each country\\\\\\\'s TAC for the shared stock

actual.comment: IFOP Chile has recently made a joint assessment of the shared anchovy stock based on their data and that posted on the IMARPE website, thus demonstrating the importance of information sharing. Seminars and workshops on top predators and methods of shared stock evaluation continued in the reporting period. Courses on the bioeconomics of fish stock recovery have been successfully delivered in both Chile and Peru by a Chilean fisheries biologist. This target only partially achieved.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Adoption of coordinated management measures for the shared stock, such as closures, quotas and exclusion areas

baseline.comment: Each country uses independent criteria for managing their part of the shared stock

target.comment: Countries use the same criteria for establishing TACs, fishing seasons and exclusion areas

actual.comment: Work towards the use of the same evaluation criteria, or at least ways of ensuring improved correlation between the methodologies use, continues. However as yet the two countries do not use the same criteria. Target partially achieved.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Increase in hectares of the coastal-marine interface under improved management - measured by RNSIIPG Master Plan and the tools for monitoring and management effectiveness measurement

baseline.comment:
RNSIIPG has not yet been established.
See ProDoc for METT score by category.
Capes and islands of the guano systems are currently managed from an extractive perspective only targeting guano birds as conservation priorities worthy of protection.

target.comment:
RNSIIPG established with a fully developed Management Plan
See ProDoc for METT score by category.
The GEF METT has been used to establish initial baseline and target values but a more specific M&E tool for marine areas will be developed in the FSP and will also be used to measure management effectiveness gains

actual.comment: Zoning work for the RNSIIPG has been advanced this reporting period. In addition a financial management plan for the protected area has been designed. A study using drone technology has been finalized to assist SERNANP and AGRORURAL to make decisions about the opening and closing of guano extraction times so as to have a minimal impact on seabirds. The METT score will be updated at the start of 2016 as part of the Final Review process. The RNSIIPG Master Plan will be approved at the end of 2015 while acknowledging that some work will remain at a range of the 33 sites not included as pilot areas under the GEF-UNDP Humboldt project.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Identification of equivalency in conservation management options (PAs) for coastal and marine environments in both countries

baseline.comment:
Peru has no specific protected area categories for marine areas, but uses terrestrial categories, that follow a gradient from direct to indirect resource use with no fully intangible protected areas.
Chile has three categories for marine areas (Marine Reserves, Marine Parks and MUMPAS).
These management schemes and categories are not equivalent for both countries

target.comment: SNAP and SINANPE MPA conservation categories defined, equated and based on a common concept for both countries

actual.comment: Work is on-going regarding a comparison of protected area legislation between the two countries. To date Peru still does not have MPAs or MUMPAs, TURFs and other territorial based co-management areas. Nevertheless the project has been instrumental in promoting Coastal Marine Spatial Planning work assisted by trainers from NOAA. This work will continue during the remainder of the Project and after closure with a direct link to the new Coastal Fisheries Initiative in Ecuador and Peru with the possibility of drawing on Chilean experience with MPAs, MUMPAs and TURFs. The GEF-UNDP Humboldt Project is developing a management plans for a new 12,000km2 MUMPA area in Chile.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of best management practices developed in the project pilot sites that are up-scaled to other protected areas

target.comment: a) Peru: 3 other sites in the RNSIIPG with management committees and plans b) Chile: at least one other canyon or seamount in the process of adoption the management options

actual.comment:
Targets achieved.
a) Good management plans regarding the start and end of guano harvesting are ready for use at all 33 RNSIIPG sites in Peru. Similarly the financial management options are available for all RNSIIPG sites and possibly Chile as well. The use of drones for assessing wildlife in isolated areas has proved to be effective.
b) Marine parks have been established around two seamounts in Chile with all seamounts receiving a degree of protection under the 2013 fisheries Law.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Implementation of pilot MPAs that underpin ecosystem conservation and resilience

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Increase in management effectiveness of the pilot MPAs measured
a) in Peru with
a) Management Plans
b) b) with the Declaration of the area in Chile
c)Management effectiveness tracking tool (METT)
METT Poor= < 25%; Fair=2650%:, Good= 5176%:; Excellent= 77100%

baseline.comment:
(a) 3 pilot areas in Peru do not have management plans; in Chile only specific fisheries (orange roughy) are currently managed in sea mounts
(b) METT values
Peru (See ProDoc Logframe for METT score by category)
Chile
Seamount 1& 2 METT 5/63 = 8% Poor

target.comment:
(a) All 3 pilots in Peru with approved management plans; Ecosystem-based management strategy for 2 sea mounts agreed on by relevant stakeholders
(b) (b) METT values
Peru (See ProDoc Logframe for METT score by category)
Chile
Seamount 1&2 METT 30% (Fair or more)

actual.comment: Targets partially achieved. The three Pilot Sites in Peru have baseline surveys, conservation plans and zoning carried out although these have not as yet been fully approved in a 33 site Management Plan. The Management Plans for the Seamounts (as Marine Parks) within the MUMPA area (JF6 - is actually outside the MUMPA area and will have to be considered separately) will be submitted semester II 2015. As mentioned above METT results will be updated early 2016 in relation to the final review process.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Reduction in the incidence of illegal extractive activities in restricted areas established in the management plans of RNSIIPG pilot sites

baseline.comment: No. of reports of illegal extractive activities will be measured once zoning of pilots is complete

target.comment: Reduction of 50% for RNSIIPG

actual.comment: Capacity building work with the management groups at each of the 33 RNSIIPG sites has successfully provided a mechanism for local level monitoring control and surveillance systems to reduce illegal activities like the use of explosives, poisons and illegal fishing gear in the areas surrounding and within the National Reserve. Although not as yet quantified via the monitoring reports a reduction of illegal activities is evident.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
3. % management costs of the pilot areas protected that have secure financing
(a) a) RNSIIPG pilots
(b) b) Seamounts

baseline.comment: As neither the RNSIIPG nor the Seamount MPA has been established there are currently no specific management costs.

target.comment:
a) 100% of the RNSIIPG pilots management costs covered of which at least 50% is from resources other than GoP
b) Seamount have identified sources for 100% management costs

actual.comment:
a) A financial management plan has been produced for the RNSIIPG as an update to the version created in 2009 prior to the RNSIIPG establishment. At present 50% of the RNSIIPG costs are covered by tourist activities associated with the 300,000 visitors per annum to the Ballestas Islands. A number which clearly puts a high level of pressure on the wildlife and increases the risk of marine accidents caused by the high speed transport of tourists to and from the Islands.
b) JF5 management costs will be included in the MUMPA management plan under development throughout 2015. However JF6 and Bajo O'Higgins, while protected under new legislation and the fact that commercial fishing boats national and foreign are obliged to carry GPS devices when operating under license in the Chilean EEZ, do not have management costs other than the work carried out by Fisheries Patrol vessels.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Ecosystem-based management strategy for sea canyons agreed on by the relevant stakeholders

baseline.comment: No specific plans for sea canyons exist

target.comment: Approved management strategy for sea canyons of the HCLME

actual.comment: While assessment work exists in both countries this is just at a very superficial level. There will be no approved sea canyon management strategy approved by the end of this phase of the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
5. Populations of flagship species at pilots
Species will be selected in yr 1

baseline.comment: Population levels (distribution and abundance) as estimated in yr 1 for selected flagship and/or indicator species in pilots

target.comment: Populations maintain at least the same levels as at the beginning of the project or are increasing

actual.comment: Data for all species is available in both countries but not shared wither within country entities or between the two countries. Data collection also comes from a range of sources both public and NGO: TNC, WWF Birdlife international). Further work needs to be carried out to coordinate datasets with ENSO occurrences. The use of drones will greatly assist this process.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To reduce CO2 emissions through the implementation of a (mandatory) energy efficiency standards and labels program

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: A) Change in annual sales towards average higher efficiency appliances (lower unit energy consumption, UEC)

baseline.comment: A) See UEC table in footnote below

target.comment: A) Reduction in average UEC (see table in footnote below) of selected household appliances: (refrigerators, refrigerator-freezers and freezers; water heaters; air conditioning equipment and washing machines) and electric motors.

actual.comment: The indicator cannot be measured yet at this point of the project implementation

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: B) Share of non-compliant products

baseline.comment: B) N/A (there is no mandatory S&L)

target.comment: B) Based on the surveys of output 2.1, the role of ´informal ´ trade will be quantified. Based on this a ´non-compliant ´ product will be defined. A preliminary aim is at least 50% should be compliant by the end of the project.

actual.comment: The indicator cannot be measured yet at this point of the project implementation

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: C) GHG emission trends

baseline.comment: C) Annual electricity demand will grow to 1000 TJ by 2018 and corresponding GHG emissions (see Figure 1 in UNDP Prodoc)

target.comment: C) The Referential Plan mentions a savings potential of 54 TJ annually by the year 2018 with corresponding cumulative GHG reduction of 35.6 million tCO2 over the period 2009-2018, of which around 5% (1,780 ktCO2) due to electricity savings by consumers (excluding lighting), motors and efficient water heaters. The estimate of direct and indirect emissions (1,217 ktCO2 over the period 2011-2018) fits within the Referential Plan ´s projections. See also Section 1 in the UNDP ProDoc for more details.

actual.comment: The indicator cannot be measured yet at this point of the project implementation

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: D) Amount of CO2 emissions avoided directly and indirectly

actual.comment: The indicator cannot be measured yet at this point of the project implementation

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced capacities of key public and private agencies to design, implement and enforce a mandatory S&L programme

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: E) Status of programs in key public agencies to implement effective mandatory S&L

baseline.comment: E) Insufficient implementation of S&L program which is in guidelines only

target.comment: E) New policy provisions and compliance checking, enforcement and outreach programs adopted that reflect international â€œbest practicesâ€

actual.comment: The Directive Committee of the project has held meetings in which it has received substantial information provided by the different consultancies/ studies undertaken during the project implementation. This learning process has enabled their capabilities for designing, implementing and enforcing a mandatory S&L program. The committee is formed by key entities in the matter, such as the Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Energy and Mines, Ministry of Production, Ministry of Economy and Finance, Ministry of External Commerce and Tourism, INDECOPI (National Institute for the defense of the competence and protection of intellectual property), SUNAT (National Superintendence of Customs and Tax Administration).

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Market transformation strategy implemented with public and private sector involvement, based on consolidated information on the market structure

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: F) Level of info available to define energy consumption in label categories and for measuring project impact

baseline.comment: F) Data available in MINEMâ€™s database, but needs to be updated and expanded

target.comment: F) Regularly updated data on annual sale and energy consumption and technology characteristics of different appliances per energy classes available

actual.comment: A study was concluded in December, 2014, with the following topics: a) structure, evolution and projection of the market related to energy equipment (refrigerator, washing machine, dryer, conditioner air machine, water heater, electric motors and boiler); b) data base of energy consumption and end use of technologies; and c) measurement of environmental, energy and economic impacts for efficiency energy labeling

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: G) Status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability (transformation strategy)

baseline.comment: G) Data available in MINEMâ€™s database, but needs to be updated and expanded

target.comment: G) Regularly updated data on annual sale and energy consumption and technology characteristics of different appliances per energy classes available for public use (with finalized market monitoring methodology)

actual.comment:
The elaboration of the strategy depends on others processes, some of them are concluded and others are in process; therefore, the strategy has not been designed yet and is scheduled for next year. The status of such processes is:
- A study related to market aspects and energy consumption, which was detailed in a point before, was concluded in December, 2014.
- Two international bids have been launched: 1) Diagnosis and Evaluation of Laboratories for Labeling; and 2) Development of a System of Conformity Assessment for the Certification of Energy Efficiency Labeling. Currently, the proposals are under evaluation.
- A study on the management, treatment and disposal of solid waste and emissions from energy equipment; the study has been launched as part of a bidding process.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Strengthened legal framework for mandatory S&L and endorsed final Technical Regulations

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: H) Status of decision-making regarding introduction of mandatory EE S&L

baseline.comment: H) Mandatory MEPS exist for CFLs; voluntary labels and MEPS for ballasts, cloth washers, fluorescent lamps, refrigerators and freezers, air conditioners and electric water heaters

target.comment: H) Decree(s) signed by the Council of Ministers on Technical regulations making labels (and/or MEPs) mandatory in the refrigerators, freezers, water heaters , washing machines and electric motors

actual.comment: 9 projects of technical regulations related to energy efficiency were concluded at the end of December, 2014. The projects were related to the following equipment: fluorescent lamps, ballasts for fluorescent lamps used in lighting for domestic purpose, refrigerators, washing machines, dryers, conditioner air machines, water heaters, electric motors and boilers. The regulation projects were published to allow the public participation during their approval process. Up to date, more than 600 public opinions have been received and evaluated. In this context, meetings with the technical body and the decision makers to reach a consensus for the approval of such regulations are ongoing.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Heightened consumer awareness and acceptance of S&L programme.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: I) Priority of different criteria used by customers in their purchasing decision and of private sector in marketing their products

baseline.comment: I) No emphasis among the consumers (and sales personnel) on energy efficiency aspects and life cycle costs when purchasing and marketing new appliances

target.comment: I) Beside the initial purchasing price, energy efficiency and life-cycle costs have become a key criteria for purchasing decisions, guided by the energy label

actual.comment: A communication strategy has been designed and a bidding process for its implementation has been launched. The strategy is targeted at consumers, to increase their awareness and acceptance to the S&L program.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Information and knowledge on S&L programme generated and shared

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: J) The level of information available for monitoring and evaluation and adaptive management

baseline.comment: J) N/A

target.comment: J) Adequate information available for adaptive management and measuring the impact.

actual.comment:
A financial audit was carried out for the period 2012-2014. The auditor recommended keeping the control and follow up as part of the project management.
The quarterly reports of the physical progress of the project were handed over timely.
